u.a: mine's = I've; voiceless bilabial plosive inserted initially;
ɡɒt tə teık əm ɒf naʊ
voiced dental fricative replaced by voiced alveolar plosive;
voiceless alveolar fricative replaced by voiceless labio-dental fricative; second element of cluster omitted;
voiced dental fricative replaced by voiced alveolar plosive;
mɑ [*] laık ə du tʰɛdi bɛə
after Jane said she liked pudding . First recorded instance of use of personal pronoun "I" .
i wɛn daʊn ɔ ðə weı ʌp
me = I; voiceless bilabial plosive inserted initially;

g.ga: I'm going to Africa for (a) long time

u.a: maı [*] ɡəu tu æfrıkə tə [*] lɒŋ taım
aı hæd ə bʌɡ tə lɑ:s naıt
maı [*] ɡʊıŋ tə ɡɛt maı stɔri bʊk
lʊk ənʌðə wʌnz nɒt kʌm ɒf
means to say ɢLook , another one has come offɦ .
pʊt dæt [*] stɔri bʊk əweı fəst
voiced dental fricative replaced by voiced alveolar plosive;

g.ga: I won't go to bed until I've had a story

u.a: ə stɔ:ri nɒt ɡəʊ tə bɛd

CHAT.comment: 1. At this stage , fall-rise is usual tune for questions , accompanied by eyebrow raising and head nodding. 2. Two tunes definitely being used - fall and fall-rise. 3. At this stage , Lucy uses "my" and "me" in subject position for "I". She also uses "mine's" , usually to replace "I am" , as in "Mine's going to kiss your cheek." 4."to" replaces "for" and "from" , as in "not too bright to Daddy" , "to long time" , "mummie come back to doctor."
